name: john
note:
I am John Johnston A Primary Teacher in Scotland. I currently teach primary 4-5-6-7 in Banton Primary, the Banton Biggies.

From 1993 until 17th October 2008 a class teacher at Sandaig Primary in Glasgow.

In 20th October 2008 I joined North Lanarkshire Council as an Educational ICT Development Officer where I was until 2016.

From January 2014 till December 2015 I was on secondment to the Scottish Government to work on Glow as Product Owner mostly on Glow Blogs. I am continuing the role on a part time basis.

content.html:
Of all the digital tools Iâ€™ve used the one that has stuck with me longest is RSS. Iâ€™ve been excited & delighted to get a peek at Feedland. Feedland is Dave Winerâ€™s latest foray into the technologies he has spent many years working on, RSS, opml & news.

As part of my peeking Iâ€™ve had the chance to produce a personal news reader. Any messiness is down to me rather than Feedland.

Over the years Iâ€™ve made a few similar things. This has been one of the easiest ways. The linked page is running on an old Raspberry Pi 2. Most of the work is done on Daveâ€™s servers but the end result was easily produced on my own.

Dave hints this is a partial sneak peek. I am looking forward to exploring and finding out more.

content.html:
Walk to Duncolm. A sparking day, photos map & notes walkmap

Iâ€™ve now plotted 61 walks on the same map which is quite interesting. Spacebar hides the map tiles for that abstract look.
content.value:
grid of photos round the map where they were taken. Autumn trees, Dumbarton Rock, Raven, reed bunting, map, kestrel, crow on a fence, hare bells, autumn trees.

content.html:
Just gathering a few podcast feeds. Problems:
1. Search finds links to podcast aggregators/apps rather than original site 2. These sites tend not to show the RSS feeds.
I know I can search & sub in Castro (or other app), but I just wanted to gather rss urls.
Mood Grumpy

content.html: We had an outdoor learning day at school yesterday. Took a snap of these pretty wee guys growing on the mossy side of a tree. No idea of species.

Listened: Really Specific Stories â€“ Daniel Jalkut

content.html:
Uh, you know, you could imagine a history of podcasting, that evolved more just like a digital version of radio, and didnâ€™t have this, this idea of a feed. And there are services out there, I think, trying to get back to a more controlled, like not, not a feed-based system,

Iâ€™ve been really enjoying dipping into Really Specific Stories which is about the creative practice of RSS-based tech podcasting. So far a lot of the episodes Iâ€™ve listened to have been from duel point of views as listeners & producers. Iâ€™ve found the â€˜listenerâ€™ views particularly compelling.

Iâ€™ve not managed to post any notes about the episodes Iâ€™ve listened to but Iâ€™am delighted that they come with full transcripts. I mostly listen to podcasts while driving, ideas pop into my head and vanish. The transcripts let me go back and skim to be reminded.

I didnâ€™t really need to skim this episode except to grab a quote. Danielâ€™s passionate arguments for RSS and publishing in the open came across very strongly. I both enjoyed and agreed with it all.

Although Really Specific Stories is about tech podcasting I think anyone with an interest in podcasting would enjoy it. Iâ€™ve listened to several episodes now and will continue to follow it.
